block.p: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

BARBARA CARROLL, Bemelmans Bar, Carlyle Hotel, 35 East 76th Street, (212) 744-1600. The agelessly chic red-haired pianist and singer seems to know every important popular song ever written and to be able to perform from memory in any key. Her elegant, lyrical pianism is a compendium of 20th-century jazz styles, from Count Basie to Erroll Garner to Bill Evans and beyond. And her clipped, understated vocals, which verge on speech-song, approach lyrics from a wry but warmhearted point of view. Through July 22. Tuesday through Saturday nights, beginning at 9:30. From 5:30 to 8, Michael Devine. No cover for early show; cover for late show: $15. No minimum; $5 cover at the bar.
Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

BARBARA CARROLL, Bemelmans Bar, Carlyle Hotel, 35 East 76th Street, (212) 744-1600. The agelessly chic red-haired pianist and singer seems to know every important popular song ever written and to be able to perform from memory in any key. Her elegant, lyrical pianism is a compendium of 20th-century jazz styles, from Count Basie to Erroll Garner to Bill Evans and beyond. And her clipped, understated vocals, which verge on speech-song, approach lyrics from a wry but warmhearted point of view. Through July 22. Tuesday through Saturday nights, beginning at 9:30. From 5:30 to 8, Michael Devine. No cover for early show; cover for late show: $15. No minimum; $5 cover at the bar.

* ''OUR SINATRA,'' Blue Angel Theater, 323 West 44th Street, Clinton, (212) 239-6200. The rising young cabaret star Eric Comstock is the mastermind behind this utterly winning tribute to Ol' Blue Eyes, which focuses on what Mr. Comstock calls the hidden gems and orphan songs that Sinatra made popular. Joined by Christopher Gines, a creamy baritone who echoes Dick Haymes and Steve Lawrence in their prime, and Hilary Kole, a perky swinger, Mr. Comstock conducts a witty and knowledgeable survey of the Sinatra canon. Mr. Comstock focuses on the mature Sinatra and Mr. Gines on the dreamy 1940's balladeer, with Ms. Kole bridging the gap. The memorable show proves there are still young singers good enough to keep the tradition alive. Today, tomorrow, Monday and Thursday nights at 8; Sunday at 3 and 7:30 p.m.; Wednesday at 2:30 and 8 p.m. Tickets: $50 and $55 (premium ringside seating, $75 and $80).

* STEVE ROSS, the Firebird Cafe, 365 West 46th Street, Clinton, (212) 586-0244. Although this debonair singer and pianist is best known for playfully inhabiting the spirits of Cole Porter, Noel Coward and Fred Astaire, he also has an introspective side. And in his superb new show, ''Love and Laughter, Part 1,'' witty romps like Porter's ''They Couldn't Compare to You'' are balanced by meditative renditions of ''All Through the Night,'' ''My Shining Hour,'' ''I Can Dream, Can't I?'' and ''One for My Baby (and One More for the Road)'' that find psychological dimensions in familiar ballads. At his most lucid, his dry, self-aware interpretations make him a philosopher of fantasy. Wednesday and Thursday nights at 9; Fridays and Saturdays at 9 and 11. Through June 3. Cover: $30; $15 minimum. Also at the Firebird, John Bucchino, Sunday night at 7, as part of the songwriters' series. Cover $20; $15 minimum. Sunday nights at 9, James Beaman as Marlene Dietrich. Through May 28. Cover: $30; $15 minimum.

* BOBBY SHORT, Cafe Carlyle, at the Carlyle Hotel, 35 East 76th Street, (212) 744-1600. Although his voice has its ups and downs, Mr. Short, now 75, still gives the best cabaret party in New York. For his 32nd spring season at the Cafe Carlyle, he is joined by a small, top-notch swing band, and he struts his bluesier pianism in the instrumental ''Moten Swing.'' Nobody puts a more vivacious spin on Cole Porter than Mr. Short, whose new show includes a boyishly wistful version of ''Why Shouldn't I?'' and the hilariously tongue-twisting, double-entendre-laden title song from ''Can-Can.'' Tuesdays through Saturdays at 8:45 and 10:45. Through June 24. Cover: $60 at tables, no minimum; $30 cover at the bar.

STEVE TYRELL, Feinstein's at the Regency, 540 Park Avenue, at 61st Street, (212) 339-4095. An affable, self-described ''Italian Texan,'' Mr. Tyrell has a gruff, soulful growl that suggests Louis Armstrong filtered through Ray Charles by way of Dr. John. In his New York club debut, he is performing popular evergreens from his recent album ''A New Standard'' (Atlantic) with a six-member band. If the singer's roustabout voice suggests a lifetime spent on the road, he needs to refine his vocal dynamics (everything is sung medium loud) and to develop looser, more improvisatory phrasing. Tonight and tomorrow night at 8:30 and 11. Cover: $60; minimum $50; dinner required for early show, with seating beginning at 6; late show, $25 minimum, with seating beginning at 10. Glen Campbell and Jimmy Webb open on Tuesday.

IRIS WILLIAMS, the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel, 59 West 44th Street, (212) 840-6800. This demure Welsh singer has one of the most striking voices in all of cabaret, a rich, dusky, buzzing contralto. Returning to the Oak Room for the first time in eight years, she is performing a program of mostly love songs, high points being ''La Vie en Rose'' (in tribute to her idol, Edith Piaf) and a deep, smoky ''I Loves You, Porgy.'' But the show is also more like a recital than a cabaret act, and the jazzier the song, the more inhibited Ms. Williams's singing becomes. Tonight and tomorrow night at 9 and 11:30. Cover: $50, with $50 prix fixe dinner required for early shows; $15 food or drink minimum for late shows; suggested dinner arrival for early show is 7. Barbara Brussell opens on Tuesday.

ARCI'S PLACE, 450 Park Avenue South, at 30th Street, (212) 532-4370. Kaye Ballard in ''Another Final Farewell Appearance.'' Friday nights at 8:30; Saturdays at 8:30 and 11; Tuesdays through Thursdays at 9. Through June 3. Also Sundays at 8, Lisa Asher, singer, with Jeff Waxman, musical director. Through May 21. Mondays, Steven Lutvak, singer. Through May 22. Cover: $25; $15 minimum.

CAFE PIERRE, Fifth Avenue at 61st Street, (212) 940-8195. Fridays and Saturdays from 8:30 p.m. to 12:30 a.m.; Tuesdays through Thursdays, 8:30 to 11:30 p.m., Kathleen Landis. Sundays and Mondays from 8:30 to 11:30, Nancy Winston. No cover or minimum.

DANNY'S SKYLIGHT ROOM, 346 West 46th Street, Clinton, (212) 265-8133. Tonight from 9 to 1, Jerry Scott; at 9:30, Laurie Krauz, singer. Tomorrow from 5 to 9 p.m. in the piano bar, Chuck Musone; at 7, Leonisa Ardizzone, singer, and the Chris Jennings Trio; from 9 to 1 in the piano bar, Mr. Scott; at 9:15, Linda Fields, singer, in ''All About Love.'' Sunday from 7 to 11, Sol Yaged and friends. Cover: free to $12; $10 minimum.
DELMONICO HOTEL, 502 Park Avenue, at 59th Street, (212) 486-0508. Two Chicks and a Casio, female singers with a backup band. Saturdays at 9 p.m. Cover: $10; no minimum.

DON'T TELL MAMA, 343 West 46th Street, Clinton, (212) 757-0788. Tonight at 6, Trevor Ashley, singer, with John Bowen, pianist; at 7, Patrick Boyd, singer, in ''Boy Oh Boy,'' with Bryan Schimmel, pianist; at 8, Eric Bettelheim, singer, with Paul Trueblood, pianist; at 9, ''Wonderfully Wickedly Weill,'' musical revue; at 10, ''Boomer Humor: Political Junkies,'' stand-up comedy. Tomorrow night at 5, Barbara Zucker-Pinchoff, singer, with Gregory Toroian, pianist; at 6, John DePalma, singer, with James Followell, pianist; at 7, Momsense, a comedy troupe; at 8, The Stand-Up Comedy Experience; at 9, ''Poole Party!,'' stand-up comedy with Ron Poole; at 11, Steven Brinberg impersonates Barbra Streisand. Sunday night at 6, Lynn Kearney, singer, with Joe Goodrich, pianist; at 9, Andrea Patterson, singer; also at 9, Jessica Hendy, singer, with Fran Minarik, pianist. Cover: Free to $15. Two-drink minimum. No credit cards.

DUPLEX, 61 Christopher Street, at Seventh Avenue South, West Village, (212) 255-5438. Tonight at 7:30, ''Lighten Up,'' comedy revue; at 10, ''Friends of Barbra,'' revue. Tomorrow night at 8, ''Bed, Boys and Beyond,'' comedy show; at 10:30, ''Foxy Ladies,'' musical revue. Cover: $7 to $15 plus two-drink minimum. No credit cards.

JOE'S PUB, Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, at Astor Place, East Village, (212) 539-8778 or (212) 239-6200. Sunday night at 8:30, Antony and the Johnsons. Tickets: $15. Monday night at 8:30, ''The Real Emotional Girl,'' Melissa Errico sings songs by Randy Newman. Through May 22. Tickets: $25.

JUDY'S CHELSEA, 169 Eighth Avenue, at 18th Street, (212) 929-5410. Tonight at 8:30, Stephanie Cheek, singer, in ''The Girl Beneath the Covers,'' with Michael McFrederick, pianist; at 11, Go Mahan, singer, in ''Astonished Heart,'' with Peter Kiesewalter, pianist. Tomorrow night at 8:30, Anthony Santelmo Jr., singer, in ''Solo,'' with Nan Butcher, pianist; at 11, Deian McBryde, singer, in ''Love, Lust and Other Distractions,'' with Bob McDowell, pianist. Sunday at 3 p.m., Jeanne Beauvais, singer, in ''A Bouquet of Song for Spring,'' with Wes McAfee, pianist; at 5:30, Yvonne Sherwell, singer, in ''Transmigration,'' with John Wallowitch, pianist; at 8:30, Leonard McKenzie, singer, in ''Lost and Found,'' with Tim Vernon, pianist. Cover: $10 to $20; $10 minimum.
SULLIVAN STREET PLAYHOUSE, 181 Sullivan Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 674-3838. Rita Gardner, singer, in ''Try to Remember: A Look at Off Broadway.'' Tomorrow night at 10. Tickets: $30.
